sentences.sentence: Resisting aggression Russia's president is banking on weaponising gas during the northern winter to trigger a democratic capitulation.

That's why we need to put our foot on the accelerator of military aid to Ukraine.As Russia and Ukraine dig in for a brutal northern winter, politics more than fighting will drive the next phase of the war.

With the war's speedometer set by the flow of Western weaponry into Ukraine and democratic leaders enabled or constrained by public will, the shaping of popular opinion makes us all critical participants in the war.Vladimir Putin is hoping soaring energy prices and economic turmoil amid a freezing winter will make military support politically unviable.Meanwhile, Volodymyr Zelensky's perpetual charm offensive to keep Ukraine top of mind has recently included the G7, the New Zealand parliament, his first trip abroad since the war began to the White House and US Congress, and even a Netflix sit-down with David Letterman.While the recent Eurobarometer poll - showing three in four Europeans endorse their government's war response - would suggest Zelensky is winning, support for military aid is weaker.Compared with 93 per cent support for humanitarian aid, only two in three Europeans back the "purchase and supply of military equipment to Ukraine".

Herein lies Putin's greatest opportunity and Ukraine's biggest risk.But anyone frustrated by high prices or hoping for a humane end to the carnage must understand there are only bad or worse choices ahead in 2023.The bad choice involves effectively arming Ukraine to expel Russia from its territory.

Doing so will be bloody and costly, but remains the least worst option to guarantee lasting peace globally.Worse choices come from the understandably tempting but deeply misguided belief that a "negotiated peace" with Putin is desirable or even possible.First, a democratic capitulation is exactly what an exhausted Putin is banking on.

Having reportedly acknowledged surprise at the fighting capacity of Ukrainians, who are "tougher than he was told", Putin has literally blown up the European gas pipes linking Russia to its largest export market, such is his determination to force democracies to gift him control of Ukraine.Second, any peace would be temporary.

Putin's obsession with erasing Ukraine, not to mention his history of deal-breaking, tells us weakness would only embolden him to return for a third bite at Ukrainian sovereignty once his armies regenerate.Third, other dictators would soon learn democratic support is limited.
Go hard enough, play for time, and eventually they'll get what they want.Mostly importantly, forcing a bad peace ignores what Ukrainians want.

With Ukraine doggedly determined to fight on and avenge Russian war crimes, a cut in military aid would make us non-innocent bystanders as Putin's armies butcher now helpless Ukrainian civilians.Inside Ukraine, amid blackouts and drone attacks, citizens are steeling themselves for a winter of no remorse.Ukraine's ambassador to Australia Vasyl Myroshnychenko tells me that even though Kyiv looks "grim" at night from the darkness cast by Putin's electricity infrastructure attacks, the city was still "bustling with Christmas spirit".

"I was greeted by an American Christmas song at the railway station, a hip coffee shop at Pushkinska Street was packed with people, and you can pick a Christmas tree at Volodymyrsky market as always," Myroshnychenko says.Kyiv radio announcer Anna Zakletska says though her station can communicate important safety information through extreme conditions and most Ukrainians are well-prepared with generators, supplies are getting low.
"Fuel is getting more expensive, and money is really not good.

We know what we are standing for," Zakletska told me from inside a bunker during a Russian air raid.A mother of three, Zakletska says the war effort has made its way onto her children's Christmas lists, even as they are forced to hide in cold and dark school shelters.
The first two were about the fast victory of Ukraine.
Others were for the safety of our home from attacks and for Ukraine's defenders to have rest.

Only her ninth wish was for Fanta and Coca-Cola," Zakletska says.Ukrainian officials have predicted a second push on Kyiv, citing Putin's meetings with Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko as proof of a northern offensive.Russia's hopeless performance so far, including its staggering recent losses in south-eastern Bahkmut - dubbed the "meat grinder" - suggests Putin's armies are flat out holding territory, let alone successfully capturing Ukraine's capital.Putin has nevertheless signalled he is digging in, reportedly telling former Israeli prime minster Naftali Bennett that although the war was harder than he thought, "we are a big country and we have patience".In his speech to the US Congress, Zelensky made clear that the war is not a contest of wills between two leaders or nations, but between two polar visions for the world.For the world to be safe, Putin must lose.

And quickly.Knowing this, the best Christmas present we can give Ukrainians and ourselves is to place our foot on the military aid accelerator, which Zelensky rightly says is not charity but "an investment in global security and democracy".Voters who complain about a lack of conviction in their leaders have an opportunity to step up.
Ukrainians are counting on it.Misha Zelinsky is a Fulbright Scholar and former assistant national secretary of the Australian Workers' Union.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: Resisting aggression Russia's president is banking on weaponising gas during the northern winter to trigger a democratic capitulation. That's why we need to put our foot on the accelerator of military aid to Ukraine.As Russia and Ukraine dig in for a brutal northern winter, politics more than fighting will drive the next phase of the war. With the war's speedometer set by the flow of Western weaponry into Ukraine and democratic leaders enabled or constrained by public will, the shaping of popular opinion makes us all critical participants in the war.Vladimir Putin is hoping soaring energy prices and economic turmoil amid a freezing winter will make military support politically unviable.Meanwhile, Volodymyr Zelensky's perpetual charm offensive to keep Ukraine top of mind has recently included the G7, the New Zealand parliament, his first trip abroad since the war began to the White House and US Congress, and even a Netflix sit-down with David Letterman.While the recent Eurobarometer poll - showing three in four Europeans endorse their government's war response - would suggest Zelensky is winning, support for military aid is weaker.Compared with 93 per cent support for humanitarian aid, only two in three Europeans back the "purchase and supply of military equipment to Ukraine". Herein lies Putin's greatest opportunity and Ukraine's biggest risk.But anyone frustrated by high prices or hoping for a humane end to the carnage must understand there are only bad or worse choices ahead in 2023.The bad choice involves effectively arming Ukraine to expel Russia from its territory. Doing so will be bloody and costly, but remains the least worst option to guarantee lasting peace globally.Worse choices come from the understandably tempting but deeply misguided belief that a "negotiated peace" with Putin is desirable or even possible.First, a democratic capitulation is exactly what an exhausted Putin is banking on. Having reportedly acknowledged surprise at the fighting capacity of Ukrainians, who are "tougher than he was told", Putin has literally blown up the European gas pipes linking Russia to its largest export market, such is his determination to force democracies to gift him control of Ukraine.Second, any peace would be temporary. Putin's obsession with erasing Ukraine, not to mention his history of deal-breaking, tells us weakness would only embolden him to return for a third bite at Ukrainian sovereignty once his armies regenerate.Third, other dictators would soon learn democratic support is limited. Go hard enough, play for time, and eventually they'll get what they want.Mostly importantly, forcing a bad peace ignores what Ukrainians want. With Ukraine doggedly determined to fight on and avenge Russian war crimes, a cut in military aid would make us non-innocent bystanders as Putin's armies butcher now helpless Ukrainian civilians.Inside Ukraine, amid blackouts and drone attacks, citizens are steeling themselves for a winter of no remorse.Ukraine's ambassador to Australia Vasyl Myroshnychenko tells me that even though Kyiv looks "grim" at night from the darkness cast by Putin's electricity infrastructure attacks, the city was still "bustling with Christmas spirit"."I was greeted by an American Christmas song at the railway station, a hip coffee shop at Pushkinska Street was packed with people, and you can pick a Christmas tree at Volodymyrsky market as always," Myroshnychenko says.Kyiv radio announcer Anna Zakletska says though her station can communicate important safety information through extreme conditions and most Ukrainians are well-prepared with generators, supplies are getting low."Fuel is getting more expensive, and money is really not good. But we keep fighting. We know what we are standing for," Zakletska told me from inside a bunker during a Russian air raid.A mother of three, Zakletska says the war effort has made its way onto her children's Christmas lists, even as they are forced to hide in cold and dark school shelters."My daughter made 10 wishes. The first two were about the fast victory of Ukraine. Others were for the safety of our home from attacks and for Ukraine's defenders to have rest. Only her ninth wish was for Fanta and Coca-Cola," Zakletska says.Ukrainian officials have predicted a second push on Kyiv, citing Putin's meetings with Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko as proof of a northern offensive.Russia's hopeless performance so far, including its staggering recent losses in south-eastern Bahkmut - dubbed the "meat grinder" - suggests Putin's armies are flat out holding territory, let alone successfully capturing Ukraine's capital.Putin has nevertheless signalled he is digging in, reportedly telling former Israeli prime minster Naftali Bennett that although the war was harder than he thought, "we are a big country and we have patience".In his speech to the US Congress, Zelensky made clear that the war is not a contest of wills between two leaders or nations, but between two polar visions for the world.For the world to be safe, Putin must lose. And quickly.Knowing this, the best Christmas present we can give Ukrainians and ourselves is to place our foot on the military aid accelerator, which Zelensky rightly says is not charity but "an investment in global security and democracy".Voters who complain about a lack of conviction in their leaders have an opportunity to step up. Ukrainians are counting on it.Misha Zelinsky is a Fulbright Scholar and former assistant national secretary of the Australian Workers' Union.
